positive.review:
Steep learning curve, but a fun sciency game once you get the hang of it. 
Would recommend learning how to program the IC chips as it helps take away some of the more repetitive tasks, auto heat / cool base, close doors, start / stop generators to charge station batteries, point solar panels towards the light etc.
Not for the feint of heart. The learning curve is steep and the game is complex, but it's a great way to scratch that engineering itch. One of my favorite games.
this game is unmatched in basic engineering design. you will get lost for hours setting up the perfect systems
The game is about the fact that you are constantly building, repairing, digging, dying...

Almost a decade since the launch and the devs still keep updating the game, funded by reasonable monetization.
A challenging space survival and builder with automation as endgame.
The best space survival game I've ever played. Never thought I would find programming in an assembly language so much fun.

This is a fantastic game with tons of depth. Something that I especially appreciate about Stationeers is that it's a survival game where survival is an actual challenge, rather than a handful of easily managed tasks/meters. Thanks to the complexity of the in-game simulation, you're never completely safe as one oversight can cause a spiral.

The core gameplay loop revolves around building your base on one of several inhospitable rocks while juggling atmospherics, temperature, food/water production, and power. This is all underscored by the ability to create and implement advanced automated systems by building on what you've already learned and writing code using an in-game scripting language to monitor, press buttons and turn dials for you.

Stationeers can best be compared to games like Stormworks and Space Station 13. If you like either of these, then it's an absolute gem worth picking up.
love the game, its a bit of a learning but the joy you feel from building your own ac to making a rocket fuel farm

An awesome game. However the autistic depth at which this game goes to is rather wild, and isn't for the faint of heart.

Oh and please remind your friend who played a lot of Space Engineers, the jetpack doesn't take hydrogen... Especially not jetpacking next to a hot vent. (Good riddance for autosaves). We sure love fireball. 

However, when you get things in place, and get a base going it can be so thrilling when things are simply stable. Because again this game is rather technical: your pipes will condense if they're cold and implode, your wires will short if there's too much current, oh and don't chuck a stack of oxyite and Volatiles into the furnace.... :).

However the stationpedia does miss critical information that requires using the unofficial one oneline. The stationpedia should be the one stop shop for all wiki info, instead it misses obvious info like how you'd use something effectively.
I think this game is underrated there are a lot of indicators you need to control in the game it has become a realistic game
This a great game that is only getting better with time.  Especially with mods.

This game is amazingly detailed. Every mechanism and click has been considered and thought out. In other games, if something feels clunky, it might actually just be clunky. In Stationeers, it is that way for a reason, maybe realism, but whatever it is, it becomes a mechanic you can respect to make each of your actions and achievements something to be proud of.

Building an Ice crusher for example, in another game it might just be a right click deploy. Done.
In Stationeers, its right click deploy, add pipes, add wires, screwdriver to finish assembly, then connect it to power, then you need pipes for the outputs, etc etc. It can be daunting, but it makes the feeling of accomplishment that much better when you do GET it.
The most in depth space survival simulator ive ever played. Steep learning curve but lots of systems to play with.

Such a fantastic game, if you like base building and micromanaging with consequences. this is your jam. Learning curve is there, and many great mods to make the game even better. (Base game is already fantastic tho, don't get me wrong)

However, for all my love of construction, the game is missing one crucial piece that would turn it from a masterpiece into a legend. Devs, I am eagerly awaiting the speedy return of abandoned bases! It is absolutely vital for me that ruins and derelicts appear in this vast world once again. I want to outfit proper expeditions, hop in a rover, and drive into the unknown to loot, loot, and loot until I'm blue in the face! Give us back the joy of scavenging and exploring ancient wrecks — it’s exactly what’s missing right now for complete perfection.

10/10 for atmosphere and physics, but please give us back that good old exploration
For someone that likes to make things go BOOM! I find it fascinating to set up experiments to watch it go critical and explode.

My last three brain cells are in a custody battle and Stationeers just got awarded full guardianship.
I installed solar panels. Backwards. I pressurized a room with pure CO2 and wondered why I was dying. I built an entire atmospheric system and forgot to connect it to anything. The game didn't stop me. It just let me cook.

If you've ever wanted to experience the crushing realization that you don't actually understand how anything works, but yet it is all still within grasp, this is your game.

This is a very addictive game. I have 270 hours logged in 24 days. It has a steep learning curve, but once you get the basics down, the game slows down from a frantic rush to a nice pace. I had passed up the game several times because the cartoony characters, but after catching it on a sale, it made me wish I had picked it up sooner. It's been a good learning experience figuring out problems, and engineering things that you worked out how to do with what you have. Would highly recommend this game and can't wait to see what else is to come.

Do you want a fun game that lets you build and explore, only to die because you mixed your hab environments gases wrong, or run out of power with no way to generate and then have to decide between backfiling your suit with 100% Nitrogen otherwise suffer a slow and painful death? then this is 100% the game for you. 

It can be challenging, and you'll probably die quite a few times but once you get your power, atmosphere and basic building sorted, it feels like an accomplishment and you are never fully out of danger.

One of my all time favorite games that I keep coming back to. For me, no playthrough is the same as I always blow myself up (along with my base). I thoroughly enjoy the figuring it out aspect  and making things work even when it doesn't make sense. Every time you think you have the game mastered, there's another layer deeper you can dive. The end of the universe is actually the limit of what you can test and do all while trying not to unalive yourself in the process.

The only negative I can say about the game is the controls do feel odd but I don't know how you could necessarily make them better given how the game works which makes steam deck play a bit cumbersome but that's just my opinion on it. I'm sure some others may disagree.

I'd still recommend this all day long.

Side note: the devs keep pushing updated refining and adding to the game and keeps it interesting. The newest update made the terrain soooo much better.

Very fun if you don't do or look at tutorials.
You may die in many different flavors, suffocation, explosion, hunger, electrocution, and others.
It will be fun and frustrating, also very rewarding.
Fun to play with friends.
Also, exemplary dev team, which really listen to the community, regular updates, a true love for their game.
I wish all dev studios out there took example on them.
hf !

Really awesome game.

Played before and after the terrain update and it's almost different games.

I keep looking for awesome views to build bases at.
Very fun space game that strikes a great balance between realism and fun. The art style matches the tone of the game quite well and gives it a very retro sci-fi feel.

Even if it's still in Early access (since 12 Dec, 2017), it's a great game. You can spent lots of time Building and refining your Base, or build completly new ones if you accidently explode your old one. 
The mechanics are detailed and can be learned while playing but can be quite tricky to master, so it is always a chalenge when you build new things. 
The game still gets updatet with new mechanics and even old ones get reworked and made better.

This game is a pure labor of love. Does it still have some occasional bugginess? yes But there is a constant stream of updates and the only time there was a pause recently was for a complete overhaul of the terrain system which was a huge improvement. You will be able to sink countless hours into this game just tinkering away at your base.  I cannot recommend this enough!

Build your own planetary/lunar outpost and manage atmospherics, agriculture and mining, eventually writing code (or, if you so desire, grabbing it from Workshop) to automate them. Very hard to get into due to barebones tutorials and UI and control scheme that take some getting used to, but extremely satisfying when you start achieving your goals. It's best to watch some videos, join the Discord (the community is generally helpful, ignore the attitude of some individuals), and expect a few restarts as you learn.

Amazing game, haven't had so much fun in a long time building a base and struggling to survive managing harsh environment, food, water, power and atmospherics. Did a few playthroughs and then decided to suffer on brutal Venus and it is Brutal but love it. The only annoying part is the pressure pulling mechanic.

This game is a long project that will take much time and effort to learn, but is quite rewarding in the process of solving the complicated challenges that it poses. If you are short on time, things will go by very slow and progress may feel glacial, but you will be equally rewarded after all is said and done.

It's difficult to review this without explaining the game in an infodumpy way, as it is a game with a lot of depth. You will be handling gases using pipes and machines to filter and control the composition and temperature of your base. You will be mining and smelting ores into alloys that require specific pressures and temperatures to form. You will be thinking quite a lot, taking stock of issues and forming ideas about solutions. There will be trial and error, there will be catastrophic failure, make frequent saves!

This game can be very intimidating but the challenge and the process is its own reward. Be ambitious and push yourself to make great things and you will get the most out of the game. don't go in expecting things to be quick and easy. the steam refund window of 2 hours is far too short for this game, so you might want to do a lot of research and watch much of this game to see if it is for you.
If you like micromanaging 400 different stats and resources, this game is for you. It's everything space engineers could have been.

It took me a while to get into this game.  I recommend watching lots of videos first.  Start on Mars in Creative where you just need to worry about power and you can take your time.  Then work on building one system at a time.  Once you learn the systems (atmosphere, water, food, etc), move to Easy mode (consumables drain slowly), then try Normal. It's an awesome game!

Stationeers is great "problems to solve generator". Entry point might seem tough since creators bearly explain basics but if you give it a chance or push your curiosity towards online beginner tutorials - you'll most likely love it. At the moment there are still minor bugs and shenanigans BUT it's still worth your time.

A Must-Have for Aspiring Engineers!

Stationeers is an immersive, hands-on learning experience for anyone interested in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). In a fun and creative way, this game challenges you to design, build, and manage your very own space station, forcing you to grapple with complex systems that mimic real-world scientific principles. From managing atmospheric pressure and gas mixtures to setting up intricate electrical grids and automated factories, Stationeers offers a deeply rewarding sandbox for creative problem-solving.

What makes Stationeers truly special is its unapologetic complexity. This is a game that respects your intelligence and rewards you for learning. You'll find yourself consulting guides and learning about thermodynamics, not because you have to, but because you'll be genuinely motivated to see your creations come to life and your station thrive in the harshness of space. The satisfaction of successfully building a self-sustaining habitat after meticulous planning and execution is unparalleled.

A huge shoutout is deserved for the small, dedicated development team at RocketWerkz. Over the years, they have shown an incredible commitment to this niche project, continuously releasing updates that have not only fixed issues but have also added massive new features and completely overhauled core systems like terrain generation. It's inspiring to see a small team so passionately dedicated to realizing such an ambitious vision.

In an industry often dominated by major studios, it is vital to support independent developers who are pushing the boundaries of what games can be. Stationeers is a shining example of a small team creating something truly unique and intellectually stimulating. If you're looking for a game that will challenge you, teach you, and give you a profound sense of accomplishment, all while supporting a deserving indie developer, then look no further than Stationeers. Highly recommended
I love this game. Controls are a little wonky but the simulation is great.

Stationeers is one of my favourite space sim games!  I love the challenge of trying to survive the harsh environments of other planets with limited resources and time.  If you enjoy designing life support systems and solving problems then this game is for you.  From the moment the door pops open on your lander, you will be faced with many challenges like building a base and all the required systems to survive like power, water, food, breathable atmosphere, shelter from storms etc.  While the game is quite complex with a steep learning curve, the in-game guide is quite useful, and there are also tons of great youtube content to help learn about all the complex systems which is awesome for beginners.  There seems to always be something new to learn from the electrical power setups to advanced atmospherics and use of integrated circuits and programming for highly automated systems etc.  If you like physics and engineering and survival, then this game is for you, highly recommend this game!!!

This game is not for the faint of heart. There will be tears, of joy and sadness, when you play this game. The game features in-depth atmospheric and logistical systems bringing about a near realistic space station building simulator. With several planets to choose from, each with their own unique challenges, this game presents players with interesting problems to solve. 

Some such problems could be heating your base on a frozen planet, providing your crops with specific temp and gas mixtures. Cooling down the same base because you overheated it. Not to mention recovering from early game power blackouts because those heaters love to consume power. 

This game is about problem solving, thinking outside the box. Instead of using power hungry heaters, why not use the output gases from your furnace? You needed to smelt those ores and alloys anyways! Stationeers truly is a fun game that gets the brain working.

This game is NOT a survival game, it's a simulator. As such it does have a slightly high learning curve. There is far too much information to be included in the game's base tutorials. Your guidebook or "Stationpedia" can always be accessed by the default key f1. There may be some reading involved! 

Don't like reading? Grab a friend, this game features multiplayer and is much more enjoyable than going solo. The discord community is full of players looking to join others! If you're new to the game, no worries, plenty of veteran players are always in the discord to help out whenever needed. 

Thank you for taking the time to read this review, though it may be bias. Thank you RocketWerkz for making such an enjoyable game!

With the new terrain update the immersion is much better than it was at launch. As usual your enemies are the world and yourself...even in the later game when you've secured resources you are still one mistake away from immediate death (for example landing a rocket with too much feul left too fast...big badda boom).  Good Stuff.
This game is a a ton of fun for those who are more technically inclined, and can be very challenging but rewarding.

Amazing!! A game that let's you do just about whatever you want within the context of a space station with awesome physics! The nature of this game, makes it my favorite game! I used to really love Space Engineers, but this is more intricate in my personal opinion. And easy to play with a simple user interface.

The tutorials suck major donkey kong. specifically the furnace and printer tutorials. They don't work right.

That was my initial response. But I picked up the learning curb, and 30 something hours later Im completely addicted. Its obvious and kudos to the devs for doing an amazing job in developing and implementing this game. Its a pleasure to play. Its like the grown up-space themed minecraft.

Either its going to hit a spot for you and thus you will put hundreds of hours in to it. Or you are going to bounce off of it hard and fast. There really isn't any middle ground.  Personally it hits the right mix of survival, legos, physics, and dwarf fortress esk you are your own worst enemy levels of !FUN for me. 

Not once have I felt like the game killed me or blew up my base.Even though deaths and explosions a plenty have happened.  The death and destruction happened because Me, Myself, and I failed, forgot, or were ignorant of something. Not because the game was out to get me. 

Personally it hits the rub goldburg thermo dynamics\phasse change physics fun of Oxygen Not Included

Building \ Legos \survival like Space engineers\rust\ark better and worse depending on aspects in question. 

And notably The self inflicted !FUN of dwarf fortress. 

I was conflicted on the other species and their unique twists being locked behind dlc when i purchaged... However I've now put  200 hours in to the base game and haven't even checked off half of my mega projects in my brain off yet. by the time I do finish that check list of ideas let alone whatever else occurs to me, Or I see in discord, or I see on reddit between now and then I'll definitely be up to throwing the devs a few more bucks for one or more of the dlcs at some point in the future when i want something new. I've already got my moneys worth out (not sale,  full msrp) it and I'm not any where near being burnt out. 

Watch lets plays \ streams of it before you buy. Again either you will fall hard for it or you will bounce off of it and want a refund. The danger is it will likely take you more than 2 hours to get thru the tutorial before you can figure out which side of that line you are on. Don't go in blind.

iv been playing this till i pass out in recent days
i skipped the tutorial and played the hardest difficulty on the moon with minimal start
have greatly enjoyed dying 20 times to 20 different ways
today i ate my own potatoes which is great achievement

at first not knowing how anything works is frustrating, but learning is great
the whole game is like playing atmos role from the game space station 13 but on hyper

now that i have reached optimizing, its just the beginning
Very immersive game, if you like simulation type games this is it. So much to unpack and learn. Highly recommend.
Fun and there some realism in the game. My first few hours were had a lot of explosions cause I had no idea how things work. Still finding creative solutions for my problems.

Absolutely amazing game 10/10. If you like a challenge this is for you.
I really do hope that development and refinement continues although there is already a ton of content.

Initially, I bought this game to support the studio while they develop KSA (Kitten Space Agency), which is might succeed to KSP (Kerbal Space Program).

However, i tried it and it is a great game mixing construction and survival. The main concept is that you have to build a base on a moon or a planet and reach self-sufficiency through mining and growing food. The building system makes me think of some mods in KSP but more stable, and with more options and serious elements of survival (energy, food, water, oxygen, carbon dioxid).

So far, I've completed the tutorials and tried my first real game, attempting to survive on the moon (my first attempt failed when a box fell on my head from the rocket and damaged my space suit).

I've seen previews of KSA on the dedicated Discord server and on Shadow Zone's Youtube channel. It is very promising so far, after one year of development. And what I saw in Stationeer gives me even more trust into the developers. Buy this game (or check Icarus, which looks gorgeous, in the vein of Ark. I didn't buy Icarus because it's not my type of game but it looks very good). KSA will be free, so buying other games by this studio is the best way to support the team.

This game started out for me as a nice game that seemed easy and got hard quick. Died a lot on my first play through and wondered why anyone would play this game for more than 10-20 hours. Then I restarted and found on the second play through that I had learned a lot and was gaining things like a stable power and base atmosphere way quicker than I did the first time, and with less base exploding. Each play through getting better.

The Good
The game is fun. You get to learn a wide variety of things including some coding. There is plenty of tutorial videos and wiki pages walking you through everything from easy to hard. You also get to decorate and design your base, or bases, however you see fit. Multiplayer works well and allows you to work together with friends to accomplish your goals. Your also not stuck on a linear path for your base and can tackle challenges in the order you see fit. A lot of workshop items and scripts for in game programming help.

The Bad
Not much for this game. Learning things can be hard, but achievable. Some of the tutorials and information is outdated. The game is still getting changes and as such sometimes your base can get broken as updates happen. Getting lost can happen, turn on that beacon before you start exploring.

All in all this game has been a lot of fun for me to play by myself and with my wife and friends. Even after getting bored and moving on to other games I always end up coming back and trying to build my base bigger or better. Worth the money over and over.

I found Stationeers after seeing someone playing it on YouTube. I wasn't sure if it would be too hard for me, but the online guides are really good and establishing basic survival wasn't that difficult. Now I'm beginning to explore some of the automation and coding and finding it quite rewarding. Great game if you like space and survival, and at 60 hours there's still so much content that I haven't even explored yet.

Absolutely amazing game. It is basically minecraft's much more intelligent and in depth older brother.
Each time I play I learn about another mechanic which is so cool to engage with. I get to use my prior computer science knowledge to program in assembly to automate stuff. very cool

At the time of this review, I accidentally overloaded my furnace with too much pressure and it blew up, killing me in the process. You are your own worst enemy in this game xD

Everyone jumps into Stationeers convinced they are basically Mark Watney with a slightly better attitude, and the game clears that illusion faster than a leaking airlock. It hands you a pile of gear, nods politely, and watches as you learn that surviving on another planet has nothing to do with inspirational monologues and everything to do with not mistaking your wrench for your welder. Within minutes you stop imagining yourself growing potatoes in heroic silence and start realising you are one misplaced click away from turning your base into a low budget vacuum experiment. Stationeers does not even bother humiliating you. It just gives you the tools, steps aside, and lets you prove that Mark Watney is a fictional character for a very good reason.

10/10, would accidentally deconstuct an atmospheric retaining wall again.

Insanely deep simulation, especially atmospherics with realistic gas mixing, pressure, cooling, heating condesation and survival systems. Programmable logic for custom automation. 
True masterpiece for hardcore builders.
The game is difficult, but not too hard with some guidance on how to get going. It goes extremely deep and is very detailed in all the right ways. I was instantly hooked.
very sharp learning curve, but that's something i love in games
Some how I gained brain cells from this game but at the same time ripped my hair out to the point of being bald 10/10

[b] A fun game with a lot of potential. If you like getting blown up, go try it out![/b] 

What I liked:
[list]
    [*]The survival aspect of the game
    [*]Customized automations through use of the in-game scripting language.
    [*]Setting up a correct mixture of gas through the use of the ideal gas law.
    [*]Phase changing of gases and liquids.
    [*]Having a vast map to build on and exploit.
    [*]Punishes you for mistakes you did a couple of in-game days prior by blowing up half your base.
    [*]Recycling used filters, bottles, equipment, etc...
    [*]Infinite resources.
[/list]
What I have mixed opinion of:
[list]
    [*]The Plant system. Why should I grow anything else than potatoes(or switchgrass/ferns for some planets)? And the genetics system isn't fun as of now.
    [*]The in-game wiki: it lacks description, some of the hyperlinks doesn't work, some of the numbers are wrong and there isn't a continuity in the use of units.
    [*]No thermal loss from walls&frames.
    [*]Unfinished features(Telescope, rover, shuttle, deep miner map)
    [*]The community, ask a question and you're sure to be reminded that you're stupid. After all... this game is not ment for stupid people? ...the community just requires some moderation.
    [*]Rocketry, after you get by the challenge of setting it up, it gets boring and overpowered.
    [*]The difficulty curve: Once you get by the challenge of acquiring steady supply of water, food and oxygen, the game game goes to "creative mode".
[/list]
What I dislike:
[list]
    [*]The trading system
[/list]

The game is continually being updated, so I believe its shortcomings will improve over time.

If you're the target audience, you'll love it.  If you're not you'll hate it. 

One thing they'll have in common, poor UI design and zero QoL.  But it's Early Access still.

I have played for 80 hours and I feel like I've barely gotten into the game.  It's crazy to me that this game is still in early access, considering how much more polished it is than many "finished" games.
Great sim, really requires you to think and is very mentally stimulating
Great fun, plenty of depth and many cool ways to die when you screw up!
They've finally started to add the game to this gas dynamics simulation.

"Oh so I just put the ice in this end of the furncae?"
"Yeah, mix it with 2:1 with oxite though. Say, where is the furnace?"
"Oh I just put it in the baseme- darn my flashlight died, these roadflares are handy though."
"The basement...? WAIT DON'T DO THAT"

And then pyro tf2 happened

I can’t express how much I enjoy Stationeers. It’s everything I wanted out of a Minecraft-style building and survival game, but in space. The dev team has done a tremendous job getting the game to a really enjoyable place, especially with the updated terrain systems – wandering around and picking a spot for a base actually feels exciting now, not just functional.

Does it do everything you’d expect from a fully open-world space exploration game? No. But what it does, it does really well. If you’ve ever wanted to live out your best “The Martian” roleplay, this is the game. The way it simulates gases and atmospherics adds a ridiculous amount of depth and tension: every leak, every pressure difference, every mistake actually matters. On top of that, the manufacturing and automation systems go just deep enough to keep you constantly engaged in upgrading, optimizing, and protecting your base without feeling like you’re drowning in complexity.

I’m always thinking one step ahead in this game—how to improve my life support, how to expand the base, what to automate next. Stationeers nails that feeling of “just one more tweak,” and suddenly you’ve lost hours. My playtime alone should give you an idea of how many hours I’ve happily sunk into this game.

If you’re into space, base building, and automation, you should definitely consider giving Stationeers a shot.

This game is incredible. Pure survival with deep deep systems like phase change simulation between matter states, pressure simulations. It’s brutal and a steep learning curve but there are some good videos on YouTube and chat GPT has helped me with some of the scripting stuff. You don’t need to use the scripting but it just automates and expands the possibilities of what you can create. 

Dean, the CEO of rocktwerkz, is one of the most passionate people I’ve ever heard speak, and has a truly pro consumer mindset. They are making a spiritual successor to one of my most beloved games KSP called Kitten Space Agency, and they’re going to be giving it away for free. I bought this game to support the studio because of that and it’s quickly become my favorite survival game ever. Thank you for all your hard work everyone over at rocketwerkz. Your passion and commitment to doing the right thing will pay off, I know it.

I started playing this game after the infamous update that many reviews are complaining about, so I don't really have much to say about this.

I will start with the issues:
- I have desyncs quite often while playing with my friend, who hosts on their computer
- When said friend hosts, they will sometimes respawn at the map's default spawn instead of the spawner they placed and interacted with (re-interracting with the spawner fixes this)
- It's quite hard to learn some things, because the included in-game wiki does not mention them at all

But [b]holy[/b] this game in incredible.

- The game runs super good
- The game saves super fast
- The netcode (with the exception desyncs) is excellent
- The physics simulation is amazing, you can roll a sheet on two cylinders, you can have 30 objects touching each others and it's fine
- The building system is [b]very[/b] nice, with layers of things you can add to decorate ... or cram more machinery in limited space
- The power system in neat, having to deal with surges and the power rating of cables
- The gas and liquid systems are great, with the valves and the pumps and you have to purge the pipes, and sometimes you have liquid in the gas pipes and have to remove it or it messes with the pressure ... it's really impressive
- The building system in steps with the separate tools is very cool, and you eventually remember what you need for each step and it's quite satisfying
- You can code in a pseudo ASM to automate things, the in-game text editor is not bad and you can make libraries of scripts to be reused in other saves/online. You can also very easily edit those scripts from your OS with your text editor of choice, and there is a VSCode extension for typing and highlight
- There is quite a complex automation game, hidden behind the survival hurdle that most people will encounter quite fast

There is so much to say, I am very happy I got this.

I didn't really expect it, but this turned out to be one of the top programming games that I've played. This game has tons of little projects contained within it, and the fact that everything is exposed to a logic network means that you can pretty much automate almost every task with the built in mips-like assembly programming language. It's basically packed with tons of projects, from small to large. Last week, I spent a bunch of time automating smelting in the advanced furnaces, which required me to figure out how to route ores from storage to the correct furnaces, how to ensure I have the right fuel mixtures and getting them into the furnace without exploding my base, how to build a custom control panel to let me know what's going on in the system and allow me to control it, and so on. Most of this work wasn't strictly necessary, but the game really just gives you a box of tools and parts and lets you go out and build whatever you feel is interesting (and if you're not careful, punishes you, too). It's a unique vibe, because the progression / pacing feels quite slow compared to other games in this genre, but I don't really care because I'm having fun just figuring stuff out and tinkering with different systems.

I would absolutely recommend this game to people who have a programming background and enjoy crunching numbers and a bit of trial and error. It really doesn't hold your hand, the tutorials are barely enough to get you started, and the game seems to have been evolving a lot over the years to the point where a lot of the docs/guides are out of date or lack information. The game describes itself as "not a casual game", and I would say that anyone looking to buy this game should really consider that warning. But if all of that doesn't scare you off, I hope you can appreciate this game as much as I do.

A true space survival simulator with a focus on atmospherics and physics. It's a challenge to get started but the game offers a variety of worlds and difficulty/start conditions so you can start "easy" and work your way to a real challenge. The UI/interactions in game are clunky at first but you learn to deal with it and then dare I say even learn to appreciate it - it does lead to some very satisfying interactions and makes you think more about your actions.

I also can not leave out thanking the developers for their continued commitment to this game and open communication. I first picked this game up years ago in EA and it's come such a long way since so I cannot wait to see what comes next.

100% would recommend to anyone who is up for a challenge and enjoys space/physics with a sprinkle of coding.

The game is really fun and insanely in-depth. When it’s working, it’s genuinely one of the most satisfying survival/engineering games out there. Topped only by the likes of Factorio (I'd even say neck and neck)

But… I don’t recommend it.

Every time you load a save, you’re basically playing Russian roulette with your progress. It might work fine, or it might just refuse to load at all. It also crashes a lot, especially while mining. And if the game decides to autosave while you’re editing terrain, congratulations that save is now a coin toss between loading later or corrupting itself permanently. Your “fix” options are either loading a much later backup (if you even have one), or resetting the terrain and hoping that doesn’t break your world even more.

These are serious bugs that should’ve been addressed immediately, but as far as I know, they haven’t even acknowledged them. Which is crazy, because everything else about this game is top tier. It’s just hard to enjoy when you’re constantly wondering if your save file’s going to detonate the next time you load it.

Motherboard: ASUS Z790 Pro RS Wifi
GPU: Nvidia 4070 Ti
CPU: Intel i9-14900K
SSD: Samsung 990 EVO 2TB
RAM: Kingston Fury 32x2 

*EDIT* I've updated my review to be positive now, a few people commented on my review and helped me figure out where the issues were coming from, and it seems they stem from a mix of the auto-save system and my PC hardware. Updating BIOS helped somewhat for a few hours, but the crashes persisted, then after trying a fresh game using only manual saves, I realized I no longer had any issues crashing. As soon as I reloaded an auto save, it began crashing again (however less frequently than before I updated BIOS)

Great game if you like managing systems to survive and thrive. Devs put an amazing amount of love into this game and the automation you can achieve is very satisfying once you get it all figured out. Online co-op too.
great and very technical base builder for those who like complex building mechanics and not just making a base look pretty.
Love the game, love the devs. If you like physics and survival youll love this game.

A while ago I found space station 13 and thought "this is neat, but it would be much more fun as a long term survival type game with all of these complex systems, rather then a round based game." that's what this is. Still has a bit of early access jank, but the complexity and number of systems in the game is so fun to try and figure out.
A fun self-torture without an end.
Can't believe I've missed this game. Exactly up my street!

Game hez Potential :)
Still missing some staf and things to by fixed but nice fun :)
Great for people who wish they were real engineers
Nice game, very complex, many awesome mods. 11/10
If the base blows up again im changing this to a negative review.
Fantastic game that I suck really bad at

Its fun, complex, makes my brain work.
^.^
makes you feel like an engineer and its fun when you get yeeted out your blown wall
Very Epic. Much Station.
build stuff, break stuff, fix stuff nad break stuff again 10/10
Insanely intricate. will definitely drive your brain nutz
LarRE has me at gun point help
I coded a solar panel movement in assembly
very challenging
it is fun
One of the best games of this type
Fun game.

negative.review:
Fix and keep your stationpedia up-to-date (ingame wiki) and I'll change my review to positive. It's lacking in updated information and is misleading for new players. You shouldn't have to look up the most basic things about a game online because of development changes. Love the game, btw.
(Also, would be nice to have a Linux version in the future)

Edit: Until in-game wiki is fixed and the developers stop promoting toxic community figures, avoid like the plague.

I really like the beginning of the game but automation is just too cumbersome for me. Why cant there be a low level automation blueprint like for airlocks for all the basic tasks like furnace, lighting, emergency power, ...
Very simple things can be done by circuits but for everything slightly complex be warned, you will have to program  automation scripts and basically everything online is outdated

the game is very fun for the first 4 or 5 hours of a save but after that the game becomes stale since survival is no longer a challenge and now your just in a annoying sandbox on top of that the game has great cover art that shows a bunch of cool stuff you can do but its all fake since most of the cover art showing the rover the shuttle and the spaceship do not exist in the game

Jesus Christ is this game shittily explained. The "tutorial" is a joke and as a new player I'm guessing you're expected to watch hours of YouTube videos to even get to the point where you don't die of thirst after the first night. This has been an excruciating hour and I've not even managed to get my helmet off so I can drink something.

In sum, this game is about as much fun as being stabbed in the belly with a rusty, blunt, tetanus-ridden knife. 0/10 would not recommend

Been trying to play with a friend and it's like pulling teeth trying to connect to his game. Not only can I not simply connect with my friends game but it's been a struggle since I started playing. There needs to be some serious rework of the multiplayer system within this game. Can't simply join my friend through steam, see his server in game as it requires you to search for the server name or ip, but it's a constant struggle to connect. The mulitplayer needs a serious update. After multiple attempts to join my friends game, restarting the game, trying again, verifying files, trying again, and even restarting my computer. I'm still unable to get to the point of putting in the password for his game. What is going on with that!!!!!!!

This could easily be my favorite game. But constant crashes and now cannot even mine for raw materials...

THUMBS DOWN

Refunded.  

I had to replay the first tutorial twice just to remember how to build a single wall segment.  It takes five confusing clicks and a hold mouse to place a single effing wall.  It runs my video card into slag even on the lowest settings (Geforce RTX 2070) and the graphics are absolutely terrible.  The UI is an abomination.  I wanted to like this one.  It's absolutely awful.

Definitely interesting, but tedious and opaque. 

What killed it for me was the air in my suit suddenly going bad. Was it bad gasses in the tank? Bad temperature? Damaged lungs? Not as far as I can tell, just "the air in your suit is damaging your lungs" with no further information. Spent a while debugging and kept passing out and dying before I gave up. Lost about 6 hours on the map without knowing why I failed. I definitely enjoy "losing is fun" type games, but there needs to be a clear reason and something to improve on next time.

The building is tedious in particular. Having to cycle between 7 different variants of wire joints and however many different rotations is obnoxious, some kind of click and drag system would do wonders. Buildings having multiple stages is somewhat interesting, but being limited to two hand slots kind of kills it, leading you to walk back and forth between storage for every single stage to pick up two sheets of plastic or whatever. There's probably some hotkey combo or flow that would make swapping things around better but I never found it so you effectively have two inventory slots in a survival-crafting-building game. It's better that that maybe sounds, but I mostly found it to be an unnecessary obstacle to doing fun base building things.
Just another Rocketwerkz nickle and dime ya to death game. where they charge you forever little item they can. the core game isnt worth a sale price either.

Nothing like fucking up a good game and making the controls so fucking stupid complex its now not worth even playing i used to love this game now its JUNK raw raw JUNK! They keep messing up the good stuff and over complex simple stuff making it so you have to hold several keys to basic actions what a waste! Maybe in a few years they will figure it out and fix it but as it is right now its such a pain to even try and play with the messed up controls!
i didnt like it i dont care what you think about it enjoy.

This could easily be my favorite game. But constant crashes and now cannot even mine for raw materials...

Refunded.  

I had to replay the first tutorial twice just to remember how to build a single wall segment.  It takes five confusing clicks and a hold mouse to place a single effing wall.  It runs my video card into slag even on the lowest settings (Geforce RTX 2070) and the graphics are absolutely terrible.  The UI is an abomination.  I wanted to like this one.  It's absolutely awful.
Just another Rocketwerkz nickle and dime ya to death game. where they charge you forever little item they can. the core game isnt worth a sale price either.

Nothing like fucking up a good game and making the controls so fucking stupid complex its now not worth even playing i used to love this game now its JUNK raw raw JUNK! They keep messing up the good stuff and over complex simple stuff making it so you have to hold several keys to basic actions what a waste! Maybe in a few years they will figure it out and fix it but as it is right now its such a pain to even try and play with the messed up controls!
i didnt like it i dont care what you think about it enjoy.
The building system is obnoxious.

Fix and keep your stationpedia up-to-date (ingame wiki) and I'll change my review to positive. It's lacking in updated information and is misleading for new players. You shouldn't have to look up the most basic things about a game online because of development changes. Love the game, btw.
(Also, would be nice to have a Linux version in the future)

Edit: Until in-game wiki is fixed and the developers stop promoting toxic community figures, avoid like the plague.

I really like the beginning of the game but automation is just too cumbersome for me. Why cant there be a low level automation blueprint like for airlocks for all the basic tasks like furnace, lighting, emergency power, ...
Very simple things can be done by circuits but for everything slightly complex be warned, you will have to program  automation scripts and basically everything online is outdated

Gameplay is fine but this game has one of the worst interface I've ever used. Building is painful and non-intuitive, and laying cables is a nightmare. The workflow, game loop and engineering parts are great but the UI ruins the experience

the game is very fun for the first 4 or 5 hours of a save but after that the game becomes stale since survival is no longer a challenge and now your just in a annoying sandbox on top of that the game has great cover art that shows a bunch of cool stuff you can do but its all fake since most of the cover art showing the rover the shuttle and the spaceship do not exist in the game
